g.title: Rectangle
g.desc: Composite Compose objects into tree structures to let clients...
g.text: Composite Compose objects into tree structures to let clients treat individual objects and compositions uniformly

g.title: Rectangle.47
g.desc: Clients need to treat a single object the same as a group of ...
g.text: Clients need to treat a single object the same as a group of objects

g.title: Folded Corner.69
g.desc: The Composite pattern compliments the Single Responsibility P...

g.text: The Composite pattern compliments the Single Responsibility Principle by shifting collection management from client to respective Composite object. This enhances the readability, reusability and testability of the code. All aspects are compared against an implementation where the client facilitates object collection management (=Composite). Readability, because client code is not obscured by ‘loops’ and collections. Extracting this logic ensures clients to remain more ‘focused’. Reusability, because multiple clients can use the same collection management (=Composite) object. The Composite object can perform collection management with Leaf objects, but also with itself. This is why the Composite should comply to the same interface as the Leaf. In contrast, having the collection logic directly in the client would result in clients to be dependent on other clients to reuse collection logic. This might result in a client being dependent on functionality it does not need. On top of that, the flexibility to compose composites out of other composites would be hard to implement. Testability, because extracting Composite logic from client logic enhances testing in isolation. The problem window of the client is decreased and composite logic can be tested separately. This enables finding bugs relatively easier and bringing code faster under test.

g.title: Folded Corner.97
g.desc: The Composite design pattern lets a client use individual and...

g.text: The Composite design pattern lets a client use individual and composite objects uniformly. A common scenario is a client that defines a collection to compose a group of objects. The collection of objects might be used in a similar fashion as a single object of that collection. The difference is that the collection is used to combine multiple results or to execute ‘bulk’ actions. The problem that might arise is increasing client complexity and duplication of collection management across the code base. The Composite pattern prescribes to ‘shift’ the responsibility of collection management to a so-called Composite class. The Composite class complies to the same interface as the individual object, called a Leaf. The client is ‘relieved’ from the responsibility and can treat collection of objects just like a single object.

g.title: Folded Corner.116
g.desc: The Composite pattern requires child management operations (e...

g.text: The Composite pattern requires child management operations (e.g. ‘Add’ and/or ‘Remove’) for the composite. These operations could be part of the Component interface. However, this violates the Interface Segregation principle, because Leafs will be dependent on functions they do not use. This could result in a default implementation in the Abstract component class. A default implementation might be an empty function. This could cause a potential bug, because the client needs to ‘carefully’ monitor the Component it works with. An empty function might cause the client to ‘think’ it works with a composite while it actually works with a leaf. Another default implementation could be to throw an exception. This however forces clients to be cautious about possible exceptions, resulting in exception handling. Exception handling causes the code complexity to grow on client side. On top of problems that arise on the client side, all Leafs must be recompiled in case child management operations change. This results in an increase in compilation time. An alternative, to a default implementation in the Component class, could be to move the child management operations to the Composite alone. However, this requires the Composite to be type casted in case we need to add or remove child elements. We end up with type checking incase we are not sure if a composite object is behind the Component interface. Again an addition to the code complexity on client side.

g.title: Folded Corner.120
g.desc: The Composite pattern compliments the Open Closed principle b...

g.text: The Composite pattern compliments the Open Closed principle by substituting single objects (=Leafs) for object collections (=Composites) without change of the client code. This ensures stability and reusability of the code base. All aspects are compared against an implementation where a client requires change when single objects are substituted for object collections. Stability, because object collections (=Composite) can be used in code where single objects (=Leaf) are used. This is possible due to both Composite and Leaf following the same interface. Preventing change in the client results in stable production and test code. Client code will not break in unexpected ways (=bugs) and test code will not require change because production code has changed. Reusability, because the client code, dependent on a single object (Leaf), can be reused with object collections (Composite).
